results.title: Dogs in Space
results.brief_description: Melbourne, Australia 1978. The punk phenomenon is sweeping the country and Dogs In Space, a punk group, are part of it. A ragtag collection of outcasts live in a squat, surviving on a diet of old TV space films, drugs and good music.

constellations_other.name: Aboriginal History Archive
constellations_other.description: The Aboriginal History Archive at Victoria University, led by Gary Foley, is dedicated to the collection and preservation of First Peoples' stories and cultural material. The political activism of the Black Power movement in the 1970s is intersected with representation of Aboriginal actors on screen.

constellations_other.name: Jill Bilcock
constellations_other.description: An editor’s work often goes unnoticed, but they’re scene-stitching not only brings the director’s vision to life but sometimes steals the show. One of Australia’s greatest editors, Jill Bilcock, has shaped some of the country’s most memorable screen stories.

constellations_other.name: Jan Chapman
constellations_other.description: From an independent Sydney cinema to the world's stage, Jan Chapman's work has many connections to the Australian film scene and Hollywood.

results.description:
Set in a share-house occupied by a collection of social misfits, the film focuses on the tumultuous affair between vivacious Anna (Saskia Post) and drug-taking Sam (Michael Hutchence), front man for the band Dogs in Space.

In his first on-screen role, Hutchence pushed against his established public persona.

As the charismatic, sexually charged front man for Australian mainstream rockers INXS, he had legions of fans that were banned from seeing their teen rock idol when the film received an R18+ rating.

With the aid of cinematographer Andrew de Groot’s invaluable camerawork, Lowenstein achieves an intense, fluid evocation of a squalid, destructive lifestyle.

Featuring a sensational post-punk soundtrack courtesy of Iggy Pop, Boys Next Door (aka Birthday Party), Brian Eno and Gang of Four, Dogs in Space has been described by Jennie Kermode in Eye for Film as “less of a film and more of an experience, a poem rather than a conventional story. It’s a remarkable testament to a piece of Australian history most people prefer to ignore.”
description_for_label:

As the charismatic, sexually charged front man for Australian mainstream rockers INXS, he had legions of fans that were banned from seeing their teen rock idol when the film received an R18+ rating.

With the aid of cinematographer Andrew de Groot’s invaluable camerawork, Lowenstein achieves an intense, fluid evocation of a squalid, destructive lifestyle.

Featuring a sensational post-punk soundtrack courtesy of Iggy Pop, Boys Next Door (aka Birthday Party), Brian Eno and Gang of Four, Dogs in Space has been described by Jennie Kermode in Eye for Film as “less of a film and more of an experience, a poem rather than a conventional story. It’s a remarkable testament to a piece of Australian history most people prefer to ignore.”

results.title: Dogs in Space
results.creator_credit: Richard Lowenstein, Glenys Rowe, Burrowes Film Group and Entertainment Media
results.brief_description: Young people enjoy the summer of 1979 in the belief that they will never grow up and join the adult world. Action centres on a Melbourne household of punks, hippies, students and radicals who represent the counter culture and the punk generation.

constellations_other.name: Black Power through film and TV
constellations_other.description: The Black Power movement of the late 1960s and early 70s was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the time and later leveraged film and TV to fight for Indigenous rights.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Richard Lowenstein, Glenys Rowe, Burrowes Film Group and Entertainment Media
results.description: A group of young people enjoy the summer of 1979 in the belief that they will never grow up and join the adult world. Action centres on a Melbourne household of punks, hippies, students and radicals who represent the counter culture and the punk generation living on sex, drugs, rock ‘n’ roll and television. Stars Michael Hutchence of INXS.

Action centres on a Melbourne household of punks, hippies, students and radicals who represent the counter culture and the punk generation living on sex, drugs, rock ‘n’ roll and television. Stars Michael Hutchence of INXS.

results.title: Dogs
results.creator_credit: Lex Van Os and FM-TV Entertainment
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Talk to the animals”.
In response to thousands of requests, the producers of Seven Network’s “Talk to the animals” have compiled this videotape for dog lovers of all ages. Now you can enjoy your favourite dog stories from Australia’s most popular television series again and again. Hosted by Dr. Harry Cooper.

results.title: Dogs
results.brief_description: Explores the world of dogs and their relationships with humans. Indicates that dog ownership means responsibility and care and that humans can learn a lot about animal behaviour by closely observing their pets. Also shows dogs that herd sheep, help police and blind people and perform tricks.

results.title: Dogs
results.creator_credit: Diane Belle James, Michael Murphy and Dimension Films
results.brief_description: A group of dogs in the countryside and at home. The camera observes in a sensitive and detailed way: as the dogs explore a stream and drink, we see how their tongues work to toss beads of water upwards; the rhythms and sounds, the ways of relating and communicating that are special to dogs. Includes a brief birth sequence.

results.title: Dogpound shuffle
results.brief_description: A tender tale about two lonely wanderers, ex-vaudevillian dancer Steps (Ron Moody) and the drifting Pritt (David Soul) who goes wherever the odd job will take him. Steps is on the road looking for his missing beloved friend, Spot the dancing dog, when he first encounters Pritt. The two strike up a friendship and find themselves in a series of misadventures as they hit the road to find the missing Spot. A story for the family - one with a happy ending.

results.title: Dogma
results.creator_credit: Kevin Smith, Scott Mosier and View Askew Productions
results.brief_description: Director/writer Kevin Smith’s (Clerks, Mallrats, Chasing Amy) comedic interpretation of the Catholic religion caused controversy before its release and continues to do so today, despite Smith’s claim that “Dogma” is about rediscovering your faith in God and shouldn’t be taken too seriously. Dwindling numbers of church-goers has caused the Catholic Church to take desperate measures to ensure its survival, beginning the ‘Catholicism Wow’ campaign, in an attempt to boost the church’s profile. Renegade angels Loki (Matt Damon) and Bartleby (Ben Affleck), banished from Heaven following an argument with God and forced to spend eternity in Wisconsin, discover a loophole in dogmatic law that will allow them to re-enter Heaven, by passing through the arch of a New Jersey Cathedral. Unfortunately God- who happens to be a woman- has failed to return from her monthly visit to earth to play arcade games. As a result the fate of the human race relies on the last descendent of Christ, Bethany (Linda Fiorentino), who has lost her faith. Metatron (Alan Rickman), a Seraphim and the voice of God, informs Bethany of her responsibilities and that she will be assisted by two prophets, Jay (Jason Mewes) and his hetro-life partner Silent Bob (played by director Kevin Smith). The unlikely trio head to New Jersey, to stop Bartleby and Loki from entering the church, because if they do, they will have proven God fallible and will wipe out all human existence. Along their way they are assisted by Rufus (Chris Rock), the 13th apostle, who claims he was left out of the bible for political reasons (and that Jesus owes him $12) and Serendipity (Salma Hayek), a muse with writers block. Cast also includes George Carlin, Jason Lee, Bud Cort, Jeff Anderson, Brian O’Halloran, Janeane Garofalo and Alanis Morissette as God.

results.title: Dog watch
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Tales of Pluto”.
Pluto, the faithful sea dog, is given responsibility of looking after the ship while the crew goes on shore leave. All goes well until a very crafty, very hungry, wharf rat sneaks on board.
